Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro have not been the exception in terms of extrasport events that will remain for history. The peculiar feature of the fossil remains is that, while skull fragments reminded of a modern man, the jaw had the characteristics of a simian. In 1953 it became clear that everything had been a deception and that the skull belonged to an anatomically modern human.

Hachiko, the Japanese dog who waited for nine years for the arrival of his dead master at a Tokyo metro station. They carried out eleven experiments with chimpanzees of the Republic of the Congo in Central Africa. The experiments confirmed results previously obtained by other researchers in the sense that chimpanzees prefer cooked foods to raw foods.

The substance oxytocin is associated with the secretion of the substance, in both, dog and owner, as a response to their mutual interaction. A similar experiment carried out with wolves did not produce the same results, despite the fact that the owners had raised them since they were puppies.

This hypothesis, however, has a logical flaw, says David Hoyle. Hoyle: The Greco painted elongated figures for aesthetic reasons and not for a visual problem.

The countries with lowest degree of microbial resistance and the least corruption are Sweden and Denmark.

Ganymede was the subject of a short story published by science fiction writer Isaac Asimov in 1940. The story is about the mining of this satellite by a private company that used the native Ganimedeans as semi-slave labor. Ganymedes has under a thick layer of surface ice an ocean of salt water that in volume is greater than all the water existing on Earth.

An article published this week in the online magazine “Science Advances” speculates in this direction.

This warming, in turn, is the result of the emission of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere by the uncontrolled burning of fossil fuels.

Fossil of stegosaurus that has been on display since last December at the Museum of Natural History of London. Philae will carry out measurements to determine its chemical composition and internal structure. Likewise, it will follow, as closely as possible, the evolution of the comet as it approaches the Sun.

Orbital Sciences Corporation rocket exploded shortly after its launch last Tuesday night from a NASA base in the state of Virginia, United States. The rocket had under contract with NASA a load of more than two tons of supplies, equipment and scientific experiments destined for the International Space Station. A second accident that involved the private space industry this week occurred last Friday when the SpaceShipTwo spacecraft of the Virgin Galactic company crashed.

Nobel Prize in Physics 2014 awarded to Japanese researchers Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano and Shuji Nakamura for invention of the LED lamp of blue light. Nobel Committee paid more attention to the social and economic impact of the discovery than to its scientific importance.

In 1865, the Augustinian monk Gregor Mendel published an article entitled “Experiences on hybridization of plants” Mendel found that the physical characteristics of the studied plants are inherited in an integral way or simply are not inherited. With this finding, Mendel gave origin to the concept of gene, a particle containing all the information of a living being.

U.S. health authorities released the first case of Ebola virus infection diagnosed in the United States. The diagnosis was made by a man who had flown days before from Liberia to Dallas, Texas. Ebola virus is known to have originated in Africa and is transmitted from animals to humans.

India has successfully launched an artificial satellite into orbit around the planet Mars. Only the United States, the former Soviet Union and the European Space Agency had managed to perform. Two other Asian countries, Japan and China, unsuccessfully tried to carry out missions to Mars. The mission had a cost of only 74 million dollars, which is just a fraction of what other Mars approach missions have cost.

NASA announced that the explorer Curiosity had finally reached the base of the five-kilometre-high Martian mountain Aeolis Mons, after a journey that took him two years. Among its stated objectives is to find out if there were ever conditions on Mars to house life. A panel of experts hired by NASA, headed by Clive Neal of the University of Notre Dame in Indiana, does not share this enthusiasm.

Fossil remains of a gigantic herbivorous dinosaur have been found in Patagonia. The newly discovered dinosaur measured about 26 meters from head to tail and weighed about 60 tons. Dinosaur has been baptized “dreadnoughtus”, which translates as “no fear”

A sample of Scottish whiskey put into orbit three years ago will land in Kazakhstan on September 12th. The experiment is carried out by the Scottish distillery Ardbeg in order to study how the microgravity conditions of space affect the process of maturation of the whiskey. Another factor that could also boost the development of factories in space is the mining of asteroids.

On August 6, a dam of the Buenavista mine in Cananea, Sonora, spilled a volume of 40,000 cubic meters of liquid in the Bacanuchi river. This liquid was a mixture of sulfuric acid and copper sulphate, in addition to other heavy metals, including cadmium, mercury and lead. With this spill, the rivers acquired a coloration as “molcajeteate salt’

In Ancient Egypt, thousands of years ago, it was customary to mummify the dead in order to preserve their bodies for eternity. Egyptologist Salima Ikram of the American University of Cairo considers that more than 70 million people were mummified in Ancient Egypt over 3000 years. In 19th century England it became fashionable to organize parties whose main attraction was to develop a mummy.

The Rosetta probe was launched ten years ago and after a long journey in which it took four laps to the Sun, it was found last August 6th with the comet Churyumov-Gerasimenko at a point about 400 million kilometers from Earth. Rosetta will enter the next six weeks in orbit around the comet and accompany it over a year as it approaches the Sun. The photographs of the comet that the probe has sent to Earth show that it has a very irregular and rough shape, formed by two well-different parts.

Nocturnal photographs of the Earth taken from space show clear signs of our presence on the planet. In number of inhabitants we have grown to some 7,000 million, at the same time as we have dispersed globally. According to environmental experts, the world is in a course of defaunation that, equally, affects the global ecological balance.

The Beatles changed their music markedly during their short career of less than a decade. A computer program was able to distinguish albums that were produced in some cases, with only months of difference. The analysis produced a phylogenetic tree that shows the evolution of Beatles’ music and indicates the musical distance between two successive albums.

The world cup of football finished a week ago with an average of 2.67 goals scored per game. If we consider only the matches of the eighth stage from the end onwards, the average of goals falls drastically to only 2.19 goals per match. As a result of this drought of goals, 12 of the 16 games after the group phase were resolved by a difference of a single goal.

Researchers carried out a genetic study with a series of hair fragments attributed to the Yeti and other abnormal primates. The hair fragments corresponded to a known animal species, including black bears, brown bears, horses, cows, raccoons, and even a porcupine. Sykes and collaborators suggest that the animals to which the fragments belong are a variant of the polar bear that had not been discovered until now. This could help explain the origin of the yeti, which would not correspond in this way to an unknown primate.

Between 1980 and 2012 the number of motor vehicles in Mexico grew by a factor of six, to reach a figure of about 35 million. In the state of San Luis Potosí this increase has been even faster. In Mexico there are approximately 300 motor vehicles per thousand inhabitants. This number is small compared to those observed in other countries.

According to the most widespread version, it was Christopher Columbus who arrived on October 12, 1492 to the island of San Salvador in the Bahamas. Some say, however, that the discoverer of America is the Viking Leif Eriksson. Others claim that the true discoverers of America were their first inhabitants, Siberians.

A new study finds that hurricanes with female names are more deadly than those with male names. The degree of femininity of the name of a hurricane determines the degree of danger with which this hurricane is judged. This would explain the greater number of fatalities associated with female hurricanes compared to male ones.

Science and technology play a fundamental role in the economic development of a country. In the present administration, CONACyT has made public the purpose of raising national spending on science and technology to 1% of the country’s gross domestic product – from the current figure of less than 0.5%. Modern technology is the daughter of science and has been able to develop properly only in countries where the latter has a naturalization charter.

Since the time we were hunters gatherers energy consumption has increased almost one hundred times. The increase has been gradual but has accelerated in the last 200 years since the Industrial Revolution. Only 13% of the electricity consumed by the world is of nuclear origin. One problem with the energy of the atom is that its exploitation generates highly toxic radioactive products.

An assistant to the Barcelona-Villareal party of the Spanish football league threw a banana at the Brazilian player Dani Alves. The event was amplified surprisingly through the internet in favor of Alves, to the extent that the author of the racist insult has problems with the police. It must be recognized, however, that racist prejudices in Europe have diminished in recent decades.

Gustavo Del Castillo and Candelario Pérez de San Luis Potosí were pioneers in the construction of scientific instruments at the UASLP. A scoundrel that faced them were the low salaries that the University could offer. Had there been better conditions for the Del Castillos project, the University would have been made of a pioneering research project in the country.

The first photograph of a person was made by Louis Daguerre in 1838. The appearance of photography allowed us for the first time to record images for posterity. An example of this is given to us by the internet site called “Mirroror of Race”

About 500,000 objects circulate in orbit around the Earth that travel at 28,000 kilometers per hour. Most of these objects are small in size – the order of a marble – about 20,000 are larger than a softball. Space debris reached notoriety in recent months because it was the subject of the film “Gravity”

Children and young people show a skill worthy of envy: to manipulate with skill gadgets that are not familiar to them. Researchers found that with certain unusual combinations of objects children outperform adults at the time of determining the correct combination. This is because children have greater flexibility to establish a cause-effect relationship in a novel situation compared to the flexibility of an adult.

In 2013 only 67% of Americans believed that the Earth was warming up, according to a Pew Research Center. For the profanate it was – and even to some extent it is – more natural to think the Earth is flat, says Dr. Frida Ghitis. The belief in global warming is not as solid as our faith in the roundness of the Earth, she says.

The “Mars One’ project, which made news this week, is certainly a very peculiar project – to say the least. It is peculiar not only because it intends to carry out a manned mission to Mars –which has no precedent – but because it seeks for astronauts to remain to colonize the planet. The project, however, does not seem to have technical viability, since Mars is at a very large distance.

1816 was, in effect, a year with an exceptionally cold climate – in England the average temperature dropped 2 degrees centigrade. It is thought it was the result of the eruption of the Tambora volcano in Indonesia in April 1815. The cooling resulting from the decrease of solar radiation brought with it bad harvests, famines and social chaos.

Solar energy could provide us with the energy we need, when in the future we run out of fossil fuels. Unfortunately, although we have solar energy in abundance, it has a basic problem: it is intermittent. We will have to develop means to store it during the day to use it at night – or in the hours when solar radiation decreases.

Traveling to Jupiter is not a simple undertaking, and it is not expected that we will do so in the coming decades. But there are those who are concerned about the food that the astronauts of the future will consume in long-term trips. In comparison, the results of space travel have been modest and the only extraterrestrial destination that has reached a manned journey is the Moon.

Nailon is an artificial material – that is, it is not found in a natural way – formed by long chains of atoms called polymers. Without the scientific discoveries made during the first half of the 20th century, silicon would not exist and consequently there would be no computers as we know them – and, of course, neither the Internet.

Antibiotics have given us a margin of safety against bacterial infections that have caused numerous epidemics and claimed numerous victims throughout the history of the world. One of the most famous, during which one third of the population of Europe would have died, is the epidemic of bubonic plague called Black Death that occurred in the 14th century.

Anthropologist Jamshid Tehrani of the University of Durham in Great Britain studied the origin of the story Caperucita Roja. Tehrani used a methodology similar to that used by biologists to determine the evolutionary path that biological species have followed. He compared the different stories and determined that Little Red Riding had as origin as El Lobo and the Cabritos.

Handcrafted work is unprecise in nature and produces imperfect objects. Industrial revolution initiated in England more than two centuries ago brought, among other things, techniques of automated manufacturing. 3D printers have brought a new sophistication in manufacturing techniques. It is intended that 4D printers produce objects with the ability to transform themselves in response to changing environmental conditions.

In the 1960s and 1970s, U.S. physicist William Shockley embarked on a campaign to convince American public opinion that the ‘quality’ of the population was declining. In reality, Shockley’s ideas were not new. Francis Galton expressed them for the first time in the second half of the 19th century, giving rise to the discipline known as eugenic.

An article and an editorial published in this week's issue of the British scientific journal “New Scientist” comment on this phenomenon. An Internet user who is anonymously connected causes, according to some opinions, that he behaves in an uncivilized way. This has been called the “toxic effect deinhibitor online”

The cover of the last issue of the British weekly newspaper “The Economist’s” is dedicated to science. It alludes to some problems that concern scientific practice, typical of the time when we lived. The scientific method is a relatively recent invention, being Galileo Galilei – in the early days – one of its main figures.

"Science" published an experiment to evaluate the editorial practices of so-called open access scientific journals. The experiment was carried out by John Bohannon, who wrote a series of false articles in which they reported alleged anti-cancer properties of a certain lichen. Free access magazines, which can be consulted free of charge via the Internet, are supported by quotas.

Free access journals charge authors between $1,000 and $2,000 per article. Some private companies publish articles with fictitious results. This limits the dissemination of research results and hinders scientific progress. In an experiment, 60% of articles that were accepted or rejected did not show signs of having experienced a peer review process.

U.N. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) released its fifth report on global warming and climate change on Friday. IPCC confirms that the burning of fossil fuels generates greenhouse gases that are producing a global climate change. The conclusions of the IPCC, however, are disputed by some, including the Heartland Institute.

Earth is approaching the inner limit of the habitable zone around the Sun, according to scientists. Once outside this area, the heat of the Sun will be so great that it will make life on Earth impossible. Scientists estimate this will happen within several billions of years, when our Sun ages and increases its size.

The term “fracking” is now in fashion in the U.S. and in Europe, and it is increasingly so in Mexico. It is used to facilitate the extraction of gas and oil from non-conventional deposits. “Fracking’ is, however, a highly controversial technology, which suffers a strong rejection by environmental groups.

Wolves have often been considered the incarnation of evil. Researchers from the University of Parma, Italy, found that wolves howl to communicate with other wolves. They found that the number of howls was in direct relation to the hierarchy that the segregated wolf had in the group. Researchers did not find a clear relationship between the level of stress and the frequency of the howls.

Spices were one of the most valuable Asian goods for Europeans. Some consider that they were the main motivation for travel. A study of mineral remains of food preserved in prehistoric peroles found in the western Baltic region. These remains, aged between 5750 and 6100 years, correspond to seeds of garlic herb.

The Anglican cathedral of the city of Christchurch in New Zealand was partially destroyed by a earthquake. The new cathedral is the work of the Japanese architect Shigueru Ban. The body of the building is formed by 98 cardboard tubes of 60 centimeters in diameter and 20 meters in length. According to its designer, the construction will have a life time of 50 years.

On July 22, NASA released a photograph of the Earth taken three days earlier from Saturn by the Cassini probe. In order to promote interest in space and achieve greater support for its projects, NASA invited the general public through its website to say “hello” to the camera at the time of taking the photograph. 20,000 people responded.

Despite what Hollywood says, it is highly unlikely that the full moon will have the power to transform a person into a werewolf. More likely this will not pass from being another invention of the film industry, based on European folklore. Some argue, however, that the Moon does influence humans, although not in such a dramatic way as to turn us into monsters.

The oil industry in Mexico was on the rise when López Velarde wrote Suave Patria (1921) Oil also had to become a source of calamities of all kinds as we all know. Industrialization, however, also has its negative aspects. The prototypic example in this sense is global warming.

The Baikonur Cosmodrome, founded in 1955, has played a prominent role in the space age. The rockets that orbited the first artificial satellite – the Sputnik I – and the bitch Laika, the first animal to travel into space, were also placed in orbit by Baikoiur. Russia, however, has decided to build a space port in its territory, in order to ‘ensure access to space’

In 1863, London’s football clubs and schools gathered in a tavern in the centre of the British capital to unify the rules of the game. Compared to its close relatives, rugby and American football, football looks like a less dangerous sport. A feature of football, however, is the use of the head to hit the ball.

Irish emigration, which existed since the beginning of the nineteenth century, accelerated in the decade of the forties of that century by the plague. The famine that followed the plague caused the death of one million Irishmen and the emigration of another. Research that unraveled the origin of the famine in Ireland are examples of how modern genetics can help us to unravel traumatic events of the past.

Researchers from Oxford University in England offer students a solution to their math problems. They stimulate a particular region of their brain by means of light electrical shocks. The relationship between electricity and living matter was discovered at the end of the 18th century. The electrical currents employed are, however, very small, so that the technique is not traumatic.

A mummified body was found in a church in La Noria, Chile, in 2003. DNA study of the body carried out by Stanford University in the U.S. showed conclusively that it was human remains. In recent weeks it was broadcast in the United States media on the occasion of the promotion of the documentary “Sirius”

According to WHO, in 2008 more than 14 billion adults over 20 years old were overweight. Of these, 200 million men and 300 million women – more than 10% of the adult population – were obese. The global obesity epidemic is due to excessive consumption of foods rich in fats and carbohydrates, as well as lack of physical exercise.

Self-medication, understood in a broad sense, is certainly a widespread practice. In some extreme cases, self-medicating is practiced even more serious situations. This includes the use of antibiotics without medical prescription, a practice that until a few years ago was possible in France.

"The Murders of Morgue Street" was published by Poe in 1841, half a century before Juan Vucetich in Argentina first used fingerprints – which are unique to each person – to solve a criminal case. After a century Poe would have taken 150 years to be born, he would have known that each individual could also be identified by his genetic code.

The origin of the Namibian fairy circles has been a mystery. The central area of these circles is devoid of vegetation and is delimited by a strip of high grass. Fairy circles are located in a region with very low rainfall in which plants absorb scarce rain and prevent them from reaching the termites.

NASA announced that the problem with the computer program that controls the Martian explorer “Curiosity” had been solved, and that within a few days it would resume its normal operation. Curiosity has two identical and redundant computers. Explorer control carries out one of these two computers, while the other acts as backup in case of need.

Japanese scientists studied the rings of the trunk of two cedars on Yaku Island in southern Japan. They found that the rings corresponding to the years 774-775 A.D. show an increase of 1.2% in their carbon concentration 14. The rise in the concentration of carbon 14 was then due to an increase in the intensity of radiation from outer space.

Russian scientist Serguei Bulat claims to have found a new type of bacteria in Lake Vostok in Antarctica. The existence of the lake was suspected since the 1950s, but not confirmed with certainty until four decades later by radar images taken from space. The forum for disseminating and discussing a scientific finding is not, of course, the one offered by the mass media, writes Alexander Nekrassov.

Researchers in the U.S. and Brazil have shown that a rat can communicate its thoughts to another rat in a laboratory in Natal, Brazil. The two rats were implanted with electrodes in the brain, through which it was possible to access the electric impulses that the same generates. The electrodes also allow the brain to be stimulated by means of external electrical impulses.

The asteroid or meteoroid that penetrated the atmosphere of our planet on Friday, February 15th, exploded about 20 kilometers high over the Cheliabinsk region in the Ural Mountains. The asteroid had a weight of between 7,000 and 10,000 tons, and by disintegrating it would have dispersed a huge amount of fragments to the delight of collectors.

In 1927, Leonid Kulik found evidence that a large asteroid had fallen 19 years earlier. Kulik knew from rumors of inhabitants of the region around Tunguska, that in 1908 a ball of fire had been seen in the sky that exploded with great noise. According to NASA, the Chelyabinsk asteroid had a size of between 15 and 17 meters, with a corresponding weight between 7,000 and 10,000 tons.

Specialists investigate the past from multiple approaches, taking advantage of circumstances and using the most diverse techniques. In this sense, we can bring to light the episode concerning the mass extinction of species – including dinosaurs – that occurred approximately 65 million years ago. As analytical techniques of all kinds are developed and increasingly sophisticated, multiply and become more sophisticated.

Timbuktu was for Europeans an exotic, mysterious and fabled place, while one of the most distant and inaccessible places in the world. Such was the fascination of Europeans by Timbuktu, that the Geographical Society in Paris offered a prize 10,000 francs to that European who arrived to that city and returned safely and safely to tell it.

The concentration of carbon dioxide in the Earth’s atmosphere has increased steadily since the beginning of the industrial revolution two centuries ago. Today, this concentration is 390 parts per million, which is 37% higher than that of 1880. Alternative energies available to replace fossil fuels include hydroelectric, wind, nuclear, geothermal, biomass.

2012 was the 10th hottest year in the world since 1880, the last year from which annual temperature records covering the entire planet are kept. 2012 was on average, according to the NOAA, 0.57 degrees Celsius hotter than the average global temperature throughout the 20th century. This, experts consider, is indicative of the global warming that currently suffers the Earth.

The Central Building of the Autonomous University of San Luis Potosí is one of the oldest buildings in the city. It was built in the seventeenth century as the headquarters of the College of the Society of Jesus. In 1923, Governor Rafael Nieto brought this institute together with the Normal School and the Civil Hospital to form a single autonomous institution.

The Virgin Galactic company offers places on its six-seater SpaceShip2 ship for the modest price of $200,000 per person on a round trip. Virgin Galactic flights – starting on a date not yet determined – will have a duration of 2 hours and will reach a height of 110 kilometers.

There are numerous recipes to alleviate the consequences of the party of the previous night. Among the most well-served remedies in our country are: a dish of often, a very spicy chilaquiles, and a soup of equally spicy shrimp. Other options include orange or tomato juice, honey with lemon, a light meal – toasted bread – or greasy – bacon sandwich.

The death of Pharaoh Tutankamon, who reigned in Egypt more than three thousand years ago, has also been a cause of speculation. Forensic research work, thousands of years away from the criminal event – which was widely commented on in days past by the mass media – appeared this week in the British Medical Journal.

The Piltdown Man turned out to be a fraud and the pieces of skull actually belonged to a modern man, while the jaw and teeth were of an orangutan. The fraud was carefully planned and more carefully executed; so much that it took 40 years to make it clear. It is still a mystery, however, who or who were the authors.

The number of rhinoceros killed by poachers has increased significantly in the last five years, says Andreas Schmitz. Rhino horns, which by weight are worth more than gold, are in demand in Asia for their supposed healing properties, he says. It should be noted that the most abundant rhino species is the white rhino, which is estimated to live about 20,000 individuals.

Some experts have associated the collapse of the Mayan civilization with prolonged episodes of drought. A 56-centimeter long stalagmite was found in a cave in Belize. Researchers were able to determine with great precision when periods of humidity and extreme drought occurred in a period of time during which the formation of the stalagmit occurred.

Study: Decision of an owner to install solar panels in his house is influenced by panels that his neighbors may have installed in their respective homes. Bollinger and Gillinham’s conclusion is derived from a study of the solar domestic facilities in the area of San Francisco Bay, California, which extends to the Silicon Valley.

Angkor Wat is a temple of great relevance to Cambodia. Its image is printed on the flag of that Southeast Asian country. The urban complex of Angkor was extending along and across an area of more than 1,000 square kilometers. This makes it the largest low density urban seat in the pre-industrial world.

British physician Andrew Wakefield was accused of inappropriate scientific conduct. Wakefield’s article and collaborators added to the growing number of scientific reports that had been withdrawn from circulation. The researchers found that the number of articles removed for all causes is increasing. Scientific fraud, which is the majority cause, has increased by a factor 10 since 1975.

Eight centuries ago Gengis Kan embarked on military campaigns that, in the course of just two decades, extended the boundaries of the Mongol Empire. Experts explain that the reason for the success of Mongols resided in the military tactics that they employed. Excess humidity would have caused more grass growth than usual and allowed support, both to horses employed in the war enterprises.

The Antarctic continent is the coldest place on Earth. The lowest temperature ever recorded was observed in 1983: less than 89 degrees Celsius. The Antarctic ice layer is also interesting because under its surface a large number of underground lakes are located. The largest of them, Lake Vostok, is of dimensions equivalent to Lake Ontario and is the seventh largest lake on the planet.

In 2010 scientists announced the discovery of fossil remains of a girl of more than 50,000 years old, in a cave in southern Siberia. The remains are of a species other than the Neanderthal but closely related species, which has become known as Denisovana. DNA has been relatively well preserved by the cold prevailing in the cave where they remained for tens of thousands of years.

On August 6, the explorer “Curiosity” entered the atmosphere of the planet Mars in a controlled manner. He has begun by sending photographs of the Martian surface, first in black and white, and then in color and high definition. There are already twelve Earth ships that have reached the surface of our neighboring planet in one way or another.

The old Yankee baseball stadium in New York was demolished in 2009 to give rise to a park. This stadium was inaugurated in 1923 and served as a home for 85 years to the Yankees of Babe Ruth, Joe Dimaggio and Mickey Mantle. The demolition of the old stadium of the Yankees can also be seen in the context of the waste it produced.

Nuclear waste is stored in pools in the same reactors that produce them, or in their vicinity. The danger that this practice represents became evident during the accident of the nuclear power plant in Fukushima. French researcher Patrick Charton presented a possible solution to the problem at the “Euroscience Open Forum” in Dublin.

The death of a famous character is by itself a cause of curiosity. This curiosity, moreover, is not reserved for recently deceased people. The case of Lenin, who died with convulsions at the age of 53 in January 1924, was studied before Lenin died in a disabled bed without being able to speak of not being monosyllable. Beethoven suffered throughout his life from a whole catalogue of diseases, including smallpox, typhus and gout.

The US company Abound Solar, which manufactures solar panels, announced this week that it will file a bankruptcy claim. That company had received a $400 million loan guarantee from the U.S. Department of Energy for the construction of two solar panel manufacturing plants in Colorado and Indiana. The loss will be absorbed by the taxes paid by US workers.

The 1960s witnessed one of the most notable events in the history of popular music. The so-called “British Invasion” to the United States began in 1964 with the arrival of the Beatles. Rock and Roll, in turn, had its roots in black music from the south of the US.

Jonathan Swift describes in ‘The travels of Gulliver’ the features of the protagonist in the country of the Liliputenses, similar to humans but only 15 centimeters high. According to Swift, the proportions of the body of dwarfs and giants would have been the same as those of our species.

Mexico is currently suffering an episode of drought that plagues several states in the center-north. It is not clear whether this drought is caused by climate change, as a major one of the world's population is suffering. Global warming, apart from the expected climate effects, could also have less obvious impacts.

The car has reached in many places in the world a predominant place and has become something indispensable and highly appreciated. In its first years of existence, the cars were often classified in the United States as dangerous vehicles. The street was conceived as a space for pedestrians – in which even children could play – cars were dangerous intruders.

Special issue of "Science" magazine looks at conflicts between humans and the violence that they derive. One article describes the finding of a series of mass graves near the site known as Tel Brak in the northeast of Syria, near the border with Iraq. This is based on the fact that the tombs did not contain remains of women, children or elderly people.

Cuban parents are giving their children invented names that are not rarely extravagant, to say the least. In some cases these are obtained by combining, more or less creatively, common names of their own. The most frequently used was “Roentgenogram,” which was replaced by the word X-ray.

Researchers from the University of British Columbia, in Canada, conclude that the strength of religious beliefs can be diminished by manipulations that induce analytical thinking. Intuitive thinking is immediate, while analytical thinking is delayed and involves a certain process of reasoning. Both types of thought coexist in our minds, although analytics can be imposed on the intuitive in certain circumstances.

Some geophysicists maintain in relation to the Wenchuan earthquake, China, which in May 2008 – a little before the Beijing Olympics – killed 80,000 people. The earthquake would be related to the Zipingpu dam near the epicenter of the tremor.

In contrast to humans, atoms are more flexible and the order within a material is determined by the way it was treated in the past. There are both ordered and disordered materials: the former are called crystals and the latter amorphous. The most striking example of natural crystal, on the other hand, is located in a cave in the state of Chihuahua.

In the work “The Chronicle of Nuremberg”, published in Germany in 1493, we find illustrations of monstrous, supposedly human beings who would have lived in the confines of the then known world. Monsters with human characteristics were not, of course, invented by the Chronicle, and on the contrary they have been a constant in our history.

In the mid-19th century, the two maternity clinics of the General Hospital of Vienna showed rates of mortality due to puerperal fever that were inexplicable at first sight. The mystery was solved by Ignaz Semmelweis, a physician associated with those clinics, who offered a surprising explanation at the time.

Perpetual motion machines would, of course, solve many of the problems that afflict our planet, such as the timely supply of oil to countries that need it. These machines would operate at a very low cost, in addition to not contributing to environmental pollution because they do not use fuel.

The adventurous spirit is, of course, not unique to Europeans nor has it been given only at a particular time. Despite their prevalence, the spirit of adventure is not widespread and, on the contrary, it is an attribute of only a minority. Researchers found that among bees there are also differences that we could classify as personality. These differences make a minority more daring than the rest when undertaking new adventures.

In 1991 two German climbers discovered the corpse of a man semi-buried on the ice in the Alps of Ötztal. The man in question – later baptized as “Ötzi, the Ice Man’ – lived and died in the Copper Age. Ötzi died a series of fortunate circumstances helped to preserve his remains for thousands of years.

With more than 1.2 billion inhabitants, India is after China the second most populous country on Earth. India is making efforts to develop in a comprehensive manner in all scientific and technological areas. India also has a vigorous space program that includes plans to put astronauts into Earth orbit – and even beyond.

New device allows controlled release of a drug for the treatment of osteoporosis. The capsule is implanted inside the body and the release of the drug is programmed wirelessly by means of an external computer. Device could be used to administer drugs for other diseases, including cancer.

Antarctica is the coldest and inhospitable continent, with an average temperature of 17 degrees Celsius below zero during the year. Under Antarctic ice, at a depth of several kilometres, there are huge lakes that have not been explored until now. Among these the largest is Lake Vostok, which has an extension of similar to Lake Ontario, on the border between the United States and Canada.

NASA announced the discovery of 11 planetary systems in our galaxy that include a total of 26 new planets. Each of the new solar systems includes two to five planets, with translation periods around their respective stars between 6 and 143 days. This discovery was made by NASA’s Kepler spacecraft, launched into space in March 2009 in an orbit around the Sun.

The Wall Street Journal reported that the Eastman Kodak company would be declaring bankruptcy at the end of this month of January or at the beginning of February.
